Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Spinal Analgesia–Epidural Analgesia and Combined Spinal–Epidural Analgesia in Reducing Neurological Complications During Labor Analgesia

Intervention.evidence: In the SA-EA group, a standard spinal needle was used for dural puncture, followed by intrathecal injection of 2mL of 0.1% ropivacaine + 1µg/mL sufentanil. An epidural catheter was inserted approximately 4cm into the epidural space. In the CSEA group, an epidural needle was used for puncture, followed by a spinal needle for dural puncture and the same intrathecal injection. An epidural catheter was inserted thereafter.

Objective.evidence: This trial aims to compare spinal analgesia–epidural analgesia (SA-EA) and combined spinal–epidural analgesia (CSEA) in mitigating these complications.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to SA-EA or CSEA groups using [Randomisation Method] with allocation concealment via [Concealment Method].

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in [Frequency and Severity by Group].
